summary:
The University of Amsterdam and TU Wien both demonstrate significant contributions to Information Retrieval (IR) and related fields, but with distinct areas of emphasis. TU Wien's research strengths lie in multimodal reachability analysis [1], consumer health search [11], and applications of Knowledge Graphs [5]. They also show a focus on practical applications in areas like clinical trial matching [6] and systematic review automation [13]. The University of Amsterdam, on the other hand, exhibits a stronger focus on neural IR [2], generative retrieval [3], and the theoretical aspects of ranking, including fairness [16] and adversarial attacks [14]. Both institutions contribute to neural ranking models [4, 8] and active learning for IR [12, 7]. However, the University of Amsterdam appears to have a broader scope within neural IR, encompassing surveys [9], graph-based approaches [10], and the role of NLP in transformers [15].

Regarding efficient information retrieval over the last 8 years, both institutions have made contributions. TU Wien has focused on local self-attention mechanisms for efficient document retrieval [5] and reachability analysis in graph-modeled collections [1]. The University of Amsterdam has explored learned index structures for index compression [1] and efficient ranking with transformers [6]. While both institutions address efficiency, the University of Amsterdam's work on learned index structures and transformer optimization seems to be more directly targeted at improving the speed and scalability of IR systems.

**References:**

[1] Sabetghadam, S., Lupu, M., Bierig, R., & Rauber, A. (2017). A faceted approach to reachability analysis of graph modelled collections. *International Journal on Digital Libraries, 19*(3), 245-262. https://doi.org/10.1007/s13735-017-0145-8

[2] Kenter, T., Borisov, A., Gysel, C., Dehghani, M., de Rijke, M., & Mitra, B. (2017). Neural Networks for Information Retrieval. *Proceedings of the 40th International ACM SIGIR Conference on Research and Development in Information Retrieval Companion*, 49-50. https://doi.org/10.1145/3077136.3082062

[3] Tang, Y., Zhang, R., Guo, J., & de Rijke, M. (2023). Recent Advances in Generative Information Retrieval. *Proceedings of the 45th European Conference on Information Retrieval*, 522-530. https://doi.org/10.1145/3624918.3629547

[4] Hofstätter, S., Rekabsaz, N., Eickhoff, C., & Hanbury, A. (2019). On the Effect of Low-Frequency Terms on Neural-IR Models. *Proceedings of the 42nd International ACM SIGIR Conference on Research and Development in Information Retrieval*, 1113-1116. https://doi.org/10.1145/3331184.3331344

[5] Hofstätter, S., Zamani, H., Mitra, B., Craswell, N., & Hanbury, A. (2020). Local Self-Attention over Long Text for Efficient Document Retrieval. *Proceedings of the 43rd International ACM SIGIR Conference on Research and Development in Information Retrieval*, 1649-1652. https://doi.org/10.1145/3397271.3401224

[6] Kusa, W., Mendoza, Ó. E., Knoth, P., Pasi, G., & Hanbury, A. (2023). Effective matching of patients to clinical trials using entity extraction and neural re-ranking. *Journal of Biomedical Informatics, 140*, 104444. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jbi.2023.104444

[7] Li, D., & Kanoulas, E. (2017). Active Sampling for Large-scale Information Retrieval Evaluation. *Proceedings of the 2017 ACM on Conference on Information and Knowledge Management*, 1533-1542. https://doi.org/10.1145/3132847.3133015

[8] Zamani, H., Dehghani, M., Croft, W. B., Learned-Miller, E., & Kamps, J. (2018). From Neural Re-Ranking to Neural Ranking. *Proceedings of the 27th ACM International Conference on Information and Knowledge Management*, 1795-1804. https://doi.org/10.1145/3269206.3271800

[9] Onal, K. D., Zhang, Y., Altıngövde, İ. S., et al. (2018). Neural information retrieval: at the end of the early years. *Information Retrieval Journal, 21*(3), 157-181. https://doi.org/10.1007/s10791-017-9321-y

[10] Li, X., de Rijke, M., Liu, Y., et al. (2020). Learning Better Representations for Neural Information Retrieval with Graph Information. *Proceedings of the 43rd International ACM SIGIR Conference on Research and Development in Information Retrieval*, 119-128. https://doi.org/10.1145/3340531.3411957

[11] Palotti, J., Zuccon, G., & Hanbury, A. (2018). Consumer Health Search on the Web: Study of Web Page Understandability and Its Integration in Ranking Algorithms (Preprint). https://doi.org/10.2196/preprints.10986

[12] Althammer, S., Zuccon, G., Hofstätter, S., Verberne, S., & Hanbury, A. (2023). Annotating Data for Fine-Tuning a Neural Ranker? Current Active Learning Strategies are not Better than Random Selection. *Proceedings of the 46th International ACM SIGIR Conference on Research and Development in Information Retrieval*, 3029-3033. https://doi.org/10.1145/3624918.3625333

[13] Kusa, W., Zuccon, G., Knoth, P., & Hanbury, A. (2023). Outcome-based Evaluation of Systematic Review Automation. *Proceedings of the 45th International ACM SIGIR Conference on Research and Development in Information Retrieval*, 2553-2557. https://doi.org/10.1145/3578337.3605135

[14] Liu, Y. A., Zhang, R., Guo, J., et al. (2022). Topic-oriented Adversarial Attacks against Black-box Neural Ranking Models. *Proceedings of the 45th International ACM SIGIR Conference on Research and Development in Information Retrieval*, 220-230. https://doi.org/10.1145/3539618.3591777

[15] Rau, D., & Kamps, J. (2022). The Role of Complex NLP in Transformers for Text Ranking. *Proceedings of the 2022 ACM SIGIR International Conference on the Theory of Information Retrieval*, 176-185. https://doi.org/10.1145/3539813.3545144

[16] Sarvi, F., Heuss, M., Aliannejadi, M., Schelter, S., & de Rijke, M. (2021). Understanding and Mitigating the Effect of Outliers in Fair Ranking. *Proceedings of the 30th ACM International Conference on Information & Knowledge Management*, 3872-3881. https://doi.org/10.1145/3488560.3498441

input.prompt: Compare the contributions of TU Wien in the field of efficient information retrieval to the University of Amsterdam contributions, over the last 8 years.
